page.title: 15Sunderland Point.
page.content: Sunderland Point is a hamlet perched on the Southern extremity of the peninsula separating the Lune estuary from Morecambe Bay. At high tide, the land forms a narrow finger almost surrounded by water; the name itself is believed to refer to the tenuous link with the mainland. The land is grassland divided into fields by cob (earth) banks and hedges, with several small pits of water. Tidal marshland and stony beaches fringe the land. A few trees grow close to the houses which perch on a shingle ridge on the estuary side of the peninsular. The houses are mainly of stone, purpose built or converted from warehouses; many are 200 to 300 years old.
